Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Rescuing a living stocks collection damaged by Hurricane Irma
Award.AbstractNarration:
A Rapid Response Research (RAPID) award is made to the Montgomery Botanical Center (MBC) to rescue 109 imperiled living stocks impacted by Hurricane Irma, which caused extensive damage to living plant collections. Initial rapid triage identified 109 living stocks that can be saved if acted upon quickly. The condition of these 109 stocks has been stabilized, and this project will enable these trees to be re-set and cared for during initial recovery. Numerous NSF-supported research projects make use of the MBC living stocks in various disciplines including systematics, physiology, ecology, paleontology. These stocks are also used in structural biology, genomics, and pollination biology studies. The collections being rescued by this project include plants of high scientific value which have extensive provenance data, prior research use, or exceptional rarity. Some of these living stocks represent the only examples held in collections, and in one case, an example of a species thought to be extinct in the wild. Living collections at MBC form the basis of MBC's outreach and educational programming, reaching students at every level from pre-K through Graduate School levels. Montgomery's formal and informal links with three nearby colleges, Miami-Dade College, Florida International University, and University of Miami, allow these living stocks to reach some of the most diverse student communities in the US. Internships at MBC incorporate collections management to help emphasize the importance of such collections for advancing science. In addition, active research on collections management by MBC and its collaborators leads to improved practice for botanic gardens and other living collections.

The project involves the initial righting and staking 109 palms which were felled by Hurricane Irma, and are in danger of desiccation and loss. Initial work involves clearing debris to allow access to these specimens. Righting the largest of these specimens will require a tree crane and backhoe working in tandem, along with a support crew to stake, backfill and water these while the crane is holding the trunk in place. The remaining palms will be righted using smaller equipment in tandem with the backhoe and support staff. After righting and staking, the stocks will require consistent management for pests and pathogens in during their re-establishment phase. This includes regular screening for pathogens, health monitoring, and collections management record keeping. Undergraduate research assistants in agroecology and horticulture will be recruited to assist with all of these skilled tasks, working directly with the curatorial staff of MBC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

In Miami-Dade County (where Montgomery Botanical Center (MBC) is located), Hurricane Irma's impacts were extensive and prolonged. Sustained winds of up to 74 mph over most of September 9 and 10, 2017 with gusts up to 100 mph reported by official sources damaged trees throughout Miami-Dade County. A storm surge of up to 6 feet above sea level impacted the landsite and living stocks of MBC, which was located in the mandatory evacuation zone A.

On September 11, 2017, MBC staff were able to initially survey the damage, and confirmed that losses were much greater for Irma than for Hurricane Wilma in 2005. At the time of assessment it appeared that at least 152 trees within the living collection were immediately lost to Irma; more impacts became apparent as symptoms in other individuals manifested.

Montgomery Botanical Center successfully saved 101 living stocks directly impacted and damaged in Hurricane Irma. These trees were righted and trimmed as appropriate to prevent their loss. These valuable collections were saved through the support of the RAPID program.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The collections focused on for this project included plants of high scientific value, due to extensive provenance data, prior research use, or exceptional rarity. In terms of rarity, some of these living stocks represent the only examples held in collections, and in one case, an example of a species extinct in the wild, with less than two dozen individuals in protective cultivation. Numerous NSF-supported research projects make use of the MBC living stocks. At least 54 of these NSF-supported projects are directly known to the curators of MBC, and these range from systematics to physiology, and include ecological, paleobotanical, and structural biology studies, as well as genomic research and pollination biology. An online list of publications involving the MBC collection can be found at http://www.montgomerybotanical.org/Pages/Research3.htm .

 

Broader Impacts:

Throughout the re-setting process, tours of the plant collection were given to elementary school students, college students, and graduate school students from local, national, and international universities. Links with Florida International University (FIU) allowed Montgomery to reach one of the most diverse student communities in the US. Leandra Gonzalez and Imena Valdes, FIU Agroecology and Biology students, were hired as Research Assistants through this award and assisted with the post-hurricane restoration of the palm collection. They provided the help that was much needed to save our living scientific collection uprighting, caring for, assessing and saving damaged palms. The internships at MBC incorporated collections management to help emphasize the importance of such collections for advancing science. Furthermore, active research on collections management by MBC and its collaborators led to improved practice for botanic gardens and other living collections. A publication discussing this project can be found online at https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/epdf/10.1111/cura.12229 , it is an open access article available to everyone online.
